Thank you Mosh for this excellent course.

results.content: Great course to quickly get up to speed with Angular 4. This isn't a 'these are the list of features and this is how to use them' course; Mosh does a good job at explaining when and why to use them, and every now and then encourages good coding practices. The exercises at the end of each section helped me see how the concepts come together in building a meaningful real world feature.

This isn't a 'these are the list of features and this is how to use them' course; Mosh does a good job at explaining when and why to use them, and every now and then encourages good coding practices. The exercises at the end of each section helped me see how the concepts come together in building a meaningful real world feature.

results.content: I'm an experienced developer but new to Angular, and really learned a lot from this intro course. I liked that the examples actually do work. What can be frustrating about other video tutorials and textbook examples is that they get outdated pretty quickly and you can end up wasting a lot of time going off on a tangent trying to figure out why the examples are not working.  I just completed this and can attest to the fact that as of this review, all the examples in the videos do work and were really helpful.  Mosh has an enthusiastic personality and keeps the topics interesting, in stark contrast to those dry computer science university course that puts everyone to sleep. Enjoy!

Good course overall.

results.content:
I like this course because for each important topic the instructor walks you through a phase 1 then you refactor and clean up the code to get to phase 5.

The result is that you learn the basics, but then you also learn how to take the code that you made and bring it to a more professional correct level.

Consuming API endpoints, dependency injection, combining observable subscriptions, clean routing and more. Exactly what I wanted to learn.

But you'll notice that as you go through the course, I'll stop repeating what I've covered before.

results.content:
This is an excellent course. Absolutely no complaints. It is well structured and explains all the key components of Angular 2 in a simple and pragmatic way.
Mosh has a great teaching style that breaks down complex concepts into smaller digestible pieces. The many code samples are small enough to make them easy to grasp, but are at the same time useful in real life coding scenarios, so they can be applied in your own projects. I loved the many "Cheat Sheets" provided in the course, which can serve as quick references on key concepts. 
Also very instructive are his comments on coding best practices. He frequently demonstrates how to refactor the code to make it more modular and reusable. So the course teaches Angular 2 but at the same time can help to improve your own coding style, which is an unexpected but valuable benefit.
Looking forward to additional courses by Mosh :-)

I originally saw this course on youtube, and registered to take it further on Udemy.
The course is straightforward, to the point, very well presented, and is separated to very meaningful and accurate parts.  

I am not a novice developer, but am a novice angular developer, which made this course perfect for me.  It did not delve to deep into each concept, but rather lightly touched on what the concept is, and applied it, allowing me to focus on the structure, and not worry about the nitty-gritty core code, as I should not worry about that anyway.  

Great job Mosh.

results.content:
Strength:

Your articulation was clear and concise. Pace was good overall. You explain why you do the things you do. At one point, I was asking myself why you group your imports the way you were doing, and a few seconds later you explained it. You stuck to your theme of keeping codes organized and clean and at various points in the presentation, you reiterated that point and showed HOW to do it. Your smile and facial expressions are professional and engaging. Keep up the good work. You take time to encourage your students that they can do it.

Areas to enhance:

Take more time on certain topics, such as Direct Injection, and dive into it a little more to ensure the reader can fully grasp the concept because so much of Angular 2 is build on it. You did try to do it with the chef conversation. Using that example earlier on and really make it simple will help. Another recommendation would be to build on one project from the beginning. Take the concepts you are talking about and build parts of that project. This will help the students build on their learning. For the final project, you can take that one project to the next level or perhaps adding another module to the project. It keeps the flow easier to follow. The third recommendation I think is beyond your control. There were various part so of the videos where it was stuck on loading with the spinner going for a long time. My internet connection was fine so I could be due to udemy. I had to manually click forward to skip a few seconds to get the video going again. Sometimes that worked and sometimes it didn't work at all. Reloading the entire page helped. From a user experience it was distracting.

results.content:
For a beginner in Angular, I must say completing and finishing this course gives me a definite perspective into the possibilities of applications in Angular 2.  The course is well drawn out and explains most of what real world web applications today require. 

The only slight drawback I felt it is the fast paced changing framework Angular itself. This course being designed to an old beta version, sometimes it feels the gap to the final version or the breaking changes are left unbridged (even though it is handled brilliant by the author)

I would really like to thank Mosh for his guidance and his brilliant efforts gone into weaving this course.
results.content_html:

Definitely, would not recommend his courses and would never purchase any of his courses again!

response.content: Hi Ahmed, if you've been following my announcements, you should know that re-creating an entire course takes several weeks if not months. I'm sorry I couldn't update the course earlier but that's just how video production works. It's extremely time consuming and slow. Nonetheless, I just updated the course to Angular 4 today! The first 10 sections are the second edition of the course recorded with Angular 4. Hope you enjoy the new videos!

results.content:
I was concerned when I saw the negative reviews about the course not being very well updated to the final release candidate, but after checking out other Angular 2 tutorials and loosing interest quickly I decided to roll the dice and try this one. It has been an awesome tutorial and is my favorite of the ones I've tried. I'm not the best coder so I was worried I wouldn't be able to follow along with the different version changes, but it ended up being very simple. I just used the original seed project provided for the course since the core concepts between the Angular 2 version in the course and the final release are essentially the same, and then once I was done I just looked up the few syntax changes in the final release.
I've taken Mosh's courses on pluralsight and of all online tutorials he has my favorite style, where he helps you not only learn new technologies but also teaches you how to write better designed code in general at the same time.
Really enjoyed taking the course and it has given me a strong grasp of Angular 2.

results.content: Very nice start into Angular2. I hope the course will be updated to the final release version soon. Until now the main block is still in the quite different syntax of beta.17, with added lessons on how to update to the newest version in the end. Since now breaking changes should have stopped it would make sense to prepare a final course update. Also there are a lot more things to learn, e.g. how to use Gulp or Grunt in Angular projects etc. Thus I hope this may be added or that there will be an advanced course following. Other than that the instructor has an amazing teaching style, which is easy to follow, while encouraging to think further and to experiment.

results.content: This course starts out strong with nice, project-based examples. However, things quickly become difficult to follow as the instructor works from different seed files, and sections stop building on top of each other. This makes it extremely difficult to understand how Angular 2 is used in context. By the time I reached the modules for building complete SPAs, I had almost no criteria for how to structure my app, and no understanding of how the various aspects of Angular 2 worked together. Additionally, these later modules turn into challenges with little-to-no-review/explanation. I understand Mosh's recommendation that you should practice on your own, but that's not the point of a course. Following Mosh through the full process of building the app would have been much more helpful, as I can practice on my own once I understand how things work. Mosh is extremely knowledgeable about this topic, but the course structure was simply too inconsistent and confusing.

results.content:
Holy shit. This is actually a really informative course! Every step taken in the videos is explained well and the knowledge is easy to convert to my own use case. 

The course contains, besides the basic knowledge, some very useful cheat sheets. The best part of this course: the video length. Most videos are at most a couple of minutes long, making it easy to stop halfway and continue later on.

The lecturer is delivering in a very engaging way and he has a clear microphone; something that is often lacking in other instruction videos around the web. You can actually hear his passion for both coding and teaching coming through!

In short: totally worth the 15 euros. I would actually buy the lecturer a coffee as a thank-you for putting all the effort in this course, but first, let me find a donate button.

results.content:
I will be reviewing the rest of the course ASAP, as my goal was to use these courses as references while working on my own ng2 apps.  As I find more and more content to be updated, I will increase my rating accordingly.

[UPDATE 20161110] I've brought my rating back up from 1 star to 2 stars.  When I started this course during RC3 (or maybe it was RC4) I gave it 4 stars and was ready to give it 5, but due to frustrations with the course content not aligning with angular docs and the instructor not keeping up with the differences in this course and the finally (lol) released ng2 final release, I was very disenchanted.

Eventually my disenchantment grew for various course content related reasons, however, I have logged in today and it appears that their have been some additional docs (while not a perfect solution) that support the course content, which show me the instructor is trying to make good on getting everything in order.  

For that reason, I give the course 2 stars in good faith.  I'm [hopefully] going to run through some of this course content over the next week or so and will happily increase my rating further if I like what I see.

Lastly, I want to make one thing clear.  Consistency of accurate and up-to-date content was the primary reason behind my lowering of ratings over the last month or so.  This course instructor does a really good job of packing in the knowledge needed to learn.  If he continues with his effective teaching style and continues to improve this course, I can tell you that it'll be on of the best around.

results.content_html:
I will be reviewing the rest of the course ASAP, as my goal was to use these courses as references while working on my own ng2 apps. As I find more and more content to be updated, I will increase my rating accordingly.

[UPDATE 20161110] I've brought my rating back up from 1 star to 2 stars. When I started this course during RC3 (or maybe it was RC4) I gave it 4 stars and was ready to give it 5, but due to frustrations with the course content not aligning with angular docs and the instructor not keeping up with the differences in this course and the finally (lol) released ng2 final release, I was very disenchanted.

Eventually my disenchantment grew for various course content related reasons, however, I have logged in today and it appears that their have been some additional docs (while not a perfect solution) that support the course content, which show me the instructor is trying to make good on getting everything in order.

For that reason, I give the course 2 stars in good faith. I'm [hopefully] going to run through some of this course content over the next week or so and will happily increase my rating further if I like what I see.

Lastly, I want to make one thing clear. Consistency of accurate and up-to-date content was the primary reason behind my lowering of ratings over the last month or so. This course instructor does a really good job of packing in the knowledge needed to learn. If he continues with his effective teaching style and continues to improve this course, I can tell you that it'll be on of the best around.

results.content:
Great course by Mosh!

This angular course is modern and uses modern tools and frameworks. He is easy to understand and the course flows quite nicely. He shows you how to set up your development environment and makes sure you have everything you need before you get started. Powerpoint slides are high quality and each section is properly laid out. He goes over the basics very well to give students a great foundation to continue to learn. He provides a cheat sheet on each section to make it easy to go back and review. Looking forward to him adding additional materials. Thanks

Thank you so much for providing a great course and I plan on signing up for more of your other courses!

results.content:
Great course, gave me enough knowlede to start out as an Angular developer and I keep referring back to it while building real application. 

Its easy to follow for a beginner, Mosh is very intuitive in his tutoring and reminds you what to do until you know it yourself, so you don't get frustrated because something is not working again.  Examples are easy to begin with and then get more complex. All important aspects are covered without being overwhelming. 

Thanks  Mosh couldn't have done it without you !

results.content:
Pitched at a level that all developers with some basic knowledge of HTML/CSS/Javascript can understand and get started easily.  (All other material I have found on Angular2+ was pitched at a level only suitable for more experienced front end developers).

The instructor is engaging and fun and his explanations are  clear , the assignments are relevant and pitched at the right level.

The one problem I had with this course is that there should be textual notes to accompany it.  Otherwise you have to go back through the videos trying to find the information you need in order to do the exercises or when doing your own development - this is very frustrating and time consuming.  Maybe that is a problem with the Udemy format rather than this course in particular??

results.content: Mosh is a very, very gifted teacher that breaks down complex topics into simple, digestible lectures which makes it easy for students to pick up Angular quickly. I've tried other courses before this one, got really frustrated and desperate. Luckily I got a recommendation to take this one and boy was I happy! Comes down to weather the teacher knows how to explain the key concepts without too much detail in the beginning so that the students don't get overwhelmed, but still give them enough valuable knowledge. And Mosh does exactly that. There have been tons of useful tips throughout the course when it comes to using shortcuts in VS Code and the terminal which are a great bonus. All in all - I am very impressed with Mosh as a teacher and highly recommend this particular course to get you up and running with Angular :)

results.content:
The course was moving along nicely until I hit the Section 8. None of the examples in that section worked at all. Section 9 was fine, but then I hit a wall again in Section 10: everything from Route Parameters on was a bust. I took a look at the final project to see if I could finish the course, but because I couldn't complete Section 10, I have no choice but to punt on the class. There really isn't any point in continuing with broken content.

One of the major problems I've found with Udemy is that instructors do not update their content in a timely manner or ignore complaints about non-functioning content/examples.

results.content:
Mosh is an excellent instructor - easy to understand, concise, has lots of exercies, and gives additional information to help remember some of the more difficult things to remember the format of.

I've been wanting to learn Angular 2 for a few months now after completing a few of the single page apps I've been developing in Angular 1.4. This course is exactly what I've been looking for. The exercises are well designed and go over the same content just taught and get more challenging as the course goes on. The exercises will start putting everything taught together.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone looking to learn Angular 2. I plan on recommending it to my colleagues and manager so we can all be on the same page in using Angular 2 in our future projects.

results.content:
Course seems more focused towards getting  the syntax right over assimilating concept . Tutor focuses mainly on explaining syntax and how one way is better than the other.

As much as I want to learn about best practices, it all seems hollow to me if tutor doesn't delve into stuff like  angular philosophy, why components are pieced together the way they are etc.

I feel I would have learnt a lot more had tutor zoomed out of each section and took sometime to give us a world view of how pieces are coming together at the end of each section. Also, I see lot of questions go unanswered.

If you're the kind of person who likes to learn by asking 'why' rather than just 'how', I'd recommend you give this one a miss.

P.S : This is a review for 50% of the course as currently I'm half way. Will update as I move forward.

results.content: This is the first of Mosh's courses I have taken, and the first course on Udemy I've fully completed! I came in to the course from a .NET background, and having mainly worked on client-side code in jQuery and similar. I did start the course when it was still Angular 2 content, but I restarted when Mosh upgraded it to Angular 4. I found the level at which Mosh teaches this course more or less perfect for me, but I also appreciated the way he structured it in the early sections - to teach beginners who are new to TypeScript the concepts of Type-safe programming. I've been busy on a number of other projects, and working on a couple of workstations. One of the machines I use dualboots Windows and Ubuntu. So for me, any time away from the lessons or switching up my environment meant coming back to absent or incomplete projects if I'd done the previous lessons on another machine. I think it would be nice if certain key lessons had a snapshot of the expected code at that point in the course. Alternatively, maybe we could use Git to sync our progress online. But in terms of content? I can't fault it! It's really sold me on the potential of the framework, and I look forward to learning some more, and trying out what I've learned on some test projects. I think the next big things to understand having done this are probably things like: user authentication, input sanitisation, and making things that would have more of an enterprise use... luckily it looks like Mosh has some courses on that sort of stuff too! Thanks Mosh, really great value, and I look forward to going through your other courses!

results.content: A good course that does exactly what it says on the tin. A very good intro to Angular 2+ while also inviting you to study yourself on the more advanced topics. If you are using Angular 6+ then you are going to come across parts which are not going to work straight away but for me that was half the learning - figuring out why this wasnt working Mosh's way in the latest version. My advice is at the minimum downgrade your bootstrap to 3.3.7.

results.content:
I am now halfway through the course, and I would recommend anyone who is new to Angular 2 to give it a shot. You truly do not need any Angular.js 1 background to follow this course.

Mosh is a very good teacher who explains everything very well, with extensive repeating. This way, you get to know the commands by heart. He includes at least one exercise after every section, that will challenge you and makes you think about how to implement it. Just like a real application. While I haven't needed it yet, I noticed he's quite active in the comments section, and tries to reply to every question, even though, as I understood, he's now on vacation.

I'm eager to learn more about the concepts around Angular 2, as I think it is a very powerful, yet complex, framework that is ready for the future.

Thank you for the great course, Mosh!

Mosh is a fantastic teacher; clear, concise and knowledgeable.

results.content:
This is the final piece I needed before starting on Mosh's ASP.NET Core course. 

As the description says, you learn two valuable skills in this course. Angular.js and TypeScript.  Mosh does a fantastic job showing you all of the core feature of Angular you need to know.  He will walk you through each feature but he also knows when to let go of your hand and let you practice on your own.  You still get enough helpful hints and tips to keep you going.  

Also, as you will have learned, this course was created between the release of Angular2 and Angular4, which is out of Mosh's control.  He does a great job to let you know all of the breaking changes and at  the time I finished the course he is rerecording portions of this course to bring it up to speed at no extra charge.  That says a lot in my opinion.

results.content:
This claims to be a practical guide but the author states he will not show how to bind the app to a backend server. I find this highly impractical. The a practical course must show how the app would save and display at least basic data from a backend server, doesn't matter if it's not angular. It's a part of the process and no angular site of any real value would work without a backend.

TOO BAD!

response.content: Sorry my friend, but I have to disagree with your definition of "impractical". Impractical means too much focused on "theory". That got nothing to do with client and server integration, which I do show in the course anyway. The final application we build in the last section is connected to a RESTful API. Sure I don't show how to build this API with ASP.NET MVC or Node or Ruby on Rails, but that's beyond the scope of Angular. If another course shows you how to do that, it's a bonus and not a requirement.
response.content_html: Sorry my friend, but I have to disagree with your definition of "impractical". Impractical means too much focused on "theory". That got nothing to do with client and server integration, which I do show in the course anyway. The final application we build in the last section is connected to a RESTful API. Sure I don't show how to build this API with ASP.NET MVC or Node or Ruby on Rails, but that's beyond the scope of Angular. If another course shows you how to do that, it's a bonus and not a requirement.

results.content_html:
This claims to be a practical guide but the author states he will not show how to bind the app to a backend server. I find this highly impractical. The a practical course must show how the app would save and display at least basic data from a backend server, doesn't matter if it's not angular. It's a part of the process and no angular site of any real value would work without a backend.

TOO BAD!

results.content: I always enjoy tutorials by Mosh because he is a great instructor with great presentations/tutorials. I did get a lot of value from this course, although I do have some complaints. The largest gripe is that it's an older version of Angular. Yes, it correctly advertises itself as an Angular 4 course. What I didn't know going in is that Angular 6 really changed things around. And because I was using a more current version of Angular, some of the things in this course didn't work as explained. Other than that, I wish the course further explained Observables, Authentication, and Architecture with modularizing your app with NgModules and lazy-loading along with using Core/Shared/Feature Modules. I hope that Mosh updates this course in the future and further goes down the rabbit hole into Angular for building enterprise apps.
results.content_html: I always enjoy tutorials by Mosh because he is a great instructor with great presentations/tutorials. I did get a lot of value from this course, although I do have some complaints. The largest gripe is that it's an older version of Angular. Yes, it correctly advertises itself as an Angular 4 course. What I didn't know going in is that Angular 6 really changed things around. And because I was using a more current version of Angular, some of the things in this course didn't work as explained. Other than that, I wish the course further explained Observables, Authentication, and Architecture with modularizing your app with NgModules and lazy-loading along with using Core/Shared/Feature Modules. I hope that Mosh updates this course in the future and further goes down the rabbit hole into Angular for building enterprise apps.

There is good explanation and easy to follow steps in the course. However, the problem is, it is at older version of Angular2. The latest version is RC5. Even after following the steps in the course, setting up a new project with latest version took me a lot of time. 
I would still give it 3.5 as it helped me a lot on getting started with Angular2 (with no prior knowledge of angular1 required) and its structure.

results.content: I was getting pretty good at Angular 1 - and when Angular 2 finally hit beta I was anxious to get going.  I wasted a lot of time learning Angular 1 on my own with A LOT of trial and error.  Angular 2 was a bit intimidating and the docs still aren't finished so I decided to spend a little on some real training.  After searching around the different 'learning' websites and reading reviews and personal profiles I decided to give Mosh's 'Angular 2 with TypeScript for Beginners: The Pragmatic Guide' a try.  This is the first course I have taken by Mr. Hamedani and I am extremely pleased at the quality of this course!  Very professionally done with excellent audio and presentation slides.  His professional knowledge of programming is obvious and I have learned a few simple tricks and 'best practices' along the way.  I'm halfway through the course and have learned more these last couple days that I would have on my own.  This won't be the last course I take by Mosh.  Thanks Mosh!
results.content_html: I was getting pretty good at Angular 1 - and when Angular 2 finally hit beta I was anxious to get going. I wasted a lot of time learning Angular 1 on my own with A LOT of trial and error. After searching around the different 'learning' websites and reading reviews and personal profiles I decided to give Mosh's 'Angular 2 with TypeScript for Beginners: The Pragmatic Guide' a try. This is the first course I have taken by Mr. Hamedani and I am extremely pleased at the quality of this course! Very professionally done with excellent audio and presentation slides. His professional knowledge of programming is obvious and I have learned a few simple tricks and 'best practices' along the way. I'm halfway through the course and have learned more these last couple days that I would have on my own. This won't be the last course I take by Mosh. Thanks Mosh!

Only reason for leaving 4stars is that there are some thing that could be explained a little better but ultimately everything was well presented.

Also i get instructor is busy, but we are paying hard earned money to understand this course, and its the job of the instructor to help us.

results.content:
Mosh has a great teaching style and rhythm for the lectures. For me, the selling point was the exercises and challenges that he provides you as a way of testing what you have just learned while still building up to previous knowledge.

The slides he uses throughout the course are really clean and simple, as well as the graphics used for simplifying otherwise hard to visualize concepts. The audio and video recordings are also really high quality.

The cheatsheet PDFs provided after each concept also come in really handy when trying to code the challenges.

I have no regrets buying this course. I'd say it's the best course on AngularJS 2 on Udemy.

results.content: I can't recommend this course unless you want to just watch lectures and not actually enter and run code. Many samples do not work. I couldn't do anything with section 5 because the favorite component does not work under recent versions of TypeScript and Node.js. Each exercise promised the instructor solution but it can't be found. It's not specified but this is not a beginners course. It starts out with the basics but quickly goes to advanced topics without enough explanation. For instance it show how to use nested FormGroups but never explains why you would want to do so. I didn't even finish this course. He lost me at consuming Http services because it tries to use deprecated HttpModule and Http. I'm not spending time trying to fix his outdated code. I'll go find another course. Disappointed.
results.content_html: I can't recommend this course unless you want to just watch lectures and not actually enter and run code. Many samples do not work. I couldn't do anything with section 5 because the favorite component does not work under recent versions of TypeScript and Node.js. Each exercise promised the instructor solution but it can't be found. It's not specified but this is not a beginners course. It starts out with the basics but quickly goes to advanced topics without enough explanation. For instance it show how to use nested FormGroups but never explains why you would want to do so. I didn't even finish this course. He lost me at consuming Http services because it tries to use deprecated HttpModule and Http. I'm not spending time trying to fix his outdated code. I'll go find another course. Disappointed.

results.content:
I understand why Mosh started this course before the final Angular API was established, but it does make this course a little bit trickier to follow. That said, Mosh added content to the course to let you know what the breaking changes were, and--let's face it--Javascript is constantly changing anyway. Get used to looking up those APIs!

I find that Mosh's courses strike a wonderful balance among pace, content, and clarity, and this course is no exception. I love that he explains what he's doing as he goes, and layers on the complexity in ways that make sense as the course continues. Before you know it, you've built something complex in a completely approachable manner.

I just finished slogging through hours of React and React Native courses, and walked away thinking that I would stick with ASP MVC until the Javascript world calms down. Thanks Mosh for restoring my hope in full-stack JS frameworks.

results.content:
This course is very good at describing the various aspects of Angular2 at a good pace, with just the right amount of repetition to make it sink in, without becoming boring.  

I really like the challenges you are set and how you are encouraged to try and make things for yourself.

My only criticism so far is that almost every concept is taught seemingly with a new project, instead of building up 1 project from start to finish, including the various things learned along the way.

results.content: Mosh has a fantastic teaching style, and just delivered the best online course I've seen in a long time. Mosh's approach to teaching and guiding makes no assumptions on existing Angular 1.x knowledge, but helps those who have to clarify new concepts. Mosh guides you through critical concepts slowly without skipping over details, and the course is extremely worth investing a few hours in, your understanding of Angular 2 will reach new levels. He fills all the gaps, presents impeccably well and the preparation was top notch, seriously can't recommend the course enough.

results.content:
Mostly, this course was what I was looking for in an Angular course.  I took an Angular course before that was over 400 lectures and which was completely unhelpful for me.  

I would have given this course a higher rating, but the material is out of date.  The course needs an update for the later versions of Angular.  It was a problem for me to be programming on Angular 9 while programming for Angular 4.

Mosh is a good instructor.  He does not waste too many words in teaching the material and he has a good delivery.  Well done, sir.  I hope to see an update for this course later.

results.content:
An excellent course!

Overview:
As someone who normally has trouble pushing through and completing online courses, I was very pleasantly surprised to find myself excited to come back to this course, even after a long day at work, and by the end I feel like I'm ready to build my own hobby projects.

Instructor:
Mosh is very skilled and pacing his lectures, and keeping an upbeat tone to his voice which helps a lot to give motivation.

Course:
The course does a very good job of jumping into the important meat of angular. Topics are built up in a way which makes you realize the importance of the feature, rather than just the syntax, by using real world component examples, such as creating a like button (like Facebook), or a vote counter (like Stack Overflow).
When a new topic requires a new library, or specific style sheet, Mosh does a great job of providing a seed project, so rather than fussing with project setup (and then getting some error different to the instructor) you can focus on learning angular itself.
The final project was also a great idea. It forced me to revise all the topics we'd learnt, and by working through each step before looking at Mosh's (very helpful) github, I feel like it solidified any topics I was unsure of.

In short, I would highly recommend this to anyone looking to learn Angular.

results.content:
In some ways I felt like this was two courses:

Part 1 goes through Section 10. In most of these lessons Mosh did a great job. He's knowledgeable and explains concepts with clarity and in-depth knowledge.

Part 2 starts with the end project for the course. I was disappointed with how this was handled and here's why:

- the pace sped up, meaning things weren't explained in detail like earlier. The project was not insignificant--the course would have been more successful if we started on the final project near the beginning of the course, as is done by many instructors, applying the knowledge as we learn it.

- almost all of the "solutions" were being told to view Mosh's code on GitHub, usually with no further explanation. I don't consider this to be teaching.

Finally, I was disappointed to see a general lack of participation by Mosh in the Q&A section. In my other courses instructors have been very hands-on (in one course the instructor even had two "interns" who helped answer questions) but here there are many questions with no response at all and many others that had to be answered by other students. I'm all for community participation and seeking answers ourselves, but when you ask people to pay for your course it's assumed you will be available to assist them when they hit roadblocks.

I still recommend this course and will likely take the more advanced course Mosh is working on now. The price is beyond fair and as a developer of 20 years I can fill in any gaps on my own. But I feel for those who come to a course like this excited and get lost, or who fail to get what they need to fully understand a concept. Sure, they can copy and paste the code from GitHub and get a running app, but that's not the point.

results.content:
This course should be 5 stars, if I'd purchased and taken 6 months ago when first released I would have happily given that rating. The instructor has done a great job, excellent pacing, in-depth instruction, very accessible style.

The caveat is Angular 2 has changed significantly now that it's final release, the course represents betas and early release candidates, there's still plenty of value, and I'm not aware of a better course right now.

The exercises in updating beta to rc1, then rc5 are extremely frustrating. At that point you're better off going to the angular website and running through the "Tour of Hero's". Debugging issues as you develop on beta releases can be complex also - keep that in mind if you take this course.
results.content_html:

The course is well done for Angular 4, I really liked how there are exercises at the end of chapters, and thought he described the mechanics Angular fairly well. But, the outdated version taught in this course soon desynchronizes with your attempts to follow along if you are using Angular 6+.  By that I mean you cannot simply follow the instructor's example and it will work on your later version.  

It's understandable, since Angular updates so frequently it is difficult to keep updating a course like this, but adding some updated coding solutions to exercises would help keep this course viable.

results.content:
I love the way Mosh teaches and I also love the pacing of this course. So far I'm 1/3 of the way there. Here are some of my thoughts:

Great things:
1. Mosh's teaching is straightforward and easy to understand.
2. Assignments are challenging enough for beginners to start getting used to Angular's environment without being overwhelmed. They are a must do if you want to learn.
3. TA replies mostly within 24hrs.

Things that can be improved:
1. Perhaps be more updated. Google releases a new version of Angular around every 6 months (with the most recent at the time of writing this Angular 8). I notice some fellow students having trouble with some assignments and following along due to change of syntax, etc.
2. Teaching assistant (as of the time writing this, the TA's name is Troy) replies fast but I sense little care in his answers. I've recently asked a question and only got half the answer. Searching up other questions I see that there are some that the TA would answer only once and would abandon even after the student expressed further troubles.


Overall, I have no background in Angular but decided to grab this course anyway because of its time length. I know anything more than 10hrs would be left unfinished by me. Even if Mosh doesn't go deep into Angular, I think it's still a great course since you get to learn the idea faster.

Very pretty and nicely structured lectures. The author explains everything in a very understandable way in a slow-medium tempo. 
Since it's a beginner-level guide, some things aren't beeing looked at deeply, which i find appropriate for the claims of this course. Although i find there could sometimes be a little bit more information on some topics.

There are a lot of exercises to improve the learning experience for each section, which i find very useful for learning and memorising purposes.

All in all i am very happy with this course so far (50% completed).

results.content:
I am a seasoned software developer but new to angular. I started reading articles online, then watched some youtube videos. When I watched Mosh's angular2 video on youtube it was obvious to me this is the right course for me to get to grisp with angular2. I love his style of teaching. He explains everything clearly and in detail without wasting time and offers exercises that really help to develop practical skills. 

Having now completed this course my final verdict is that it has been worth my time. It has been an engaging and enjoyable learning experience. I have enough angular2 knowledge now to be able to use it in real life projects. My main reason for learning angular2 is that I want to learn mobile apps development using ionic framework which is based on angular2. Now I can begin learning ionic effectively with confidence. I look forward to taking more courses from Mosh. Thank you Mosh.

results.content:
I really don't care how much you've got on your plate.  I paid for *this* course.  You have an obligation to deliver on *this* course.

Tacking appendices to the end of the course does not update the course to final release.  It's a stop gap measure.  "Take the course, then read about the parts that you just learned that aren't valid any more."  Not exactly ideal.

If this is your idea of supporting those of us who put down good money in the expectation that you would stand behind your product, well you'll have to work really, really hard to get me to pay for another one of your offerings.  To say you've disappointed me is an understatement.
results.content_html:

results.content: So far, some of the directions for installing and creating a project in angular were out of date and I had to google a bit to get up-to-date instructions.  But that is understandable/maybe unavoidable because new updates come out all the time.  In particular, after creating a new project (ng new hello-world), I had to answer some questions like "Would like to add Angular routing."  The instructor didnt' have answer this question or it wasn't necessary on his outdated version.  So I had to google that.  Also, in terminal I had to do "ng serve -o" instead of "ng serve" (like the instructory) in order to get the same results as the instructor- that is, to start the application in the browser.

results.content:
Had to resolve some issues caused by updates to tools & libraries.   Had to uninstall bootstrap 4 and reinstall bootstrap via bootstrap@3 to get icons to work.  The nav-bar .collapsed class did not work correctly for me on last routing exercise.  Had to remove it (words were invisible).    I would prefer he instruct us to save the current project (via version control) before erasing things to add different code, so I could go back and refer to things from previous lectures more easily, or start new projects more often.  (Final version had many components that had no remaining references to them).

Still, very informative and well done.

results.content: I've studied programming quite a lot by watching video tutorial courses/ universities during the past years. This is some of the best I've seen so far! Many courses are trying to show the bigger picture first or asap (which often is totally fine to do), and targeting specific concepts later (Symfony first, understanding Doctrine in detail later... e.g.). Mosh goes the opposite way: Concepts first! The bigger picture comes at the end of this course. In respect to the complexity of Angular2 (and I find Angular2 quite complex compared to backend-frameworks like eg. Django or Symfony, I admit) this totally makes sense. Excellent work!! Looking forward to the advanced course!!

results.content: The instructor is top notch, he explains every section in great detail. I particularly liked the section about Reative Extentions. I Would have given this course a 4.5 or even a 5, except there is a problem. The course says angular 2, but many videos have angular-pre release content. Yes, he does have an appendix where he indicates the changes from beta-release candidate to release but this is not ideal for a course you have to pay for. I would expect the instructor to redo all the videos to run smoothly for version 2, and remove the appendix; if this is done I would give this course a 4.5 or 5. Angular 2 is a big enough framework, and having to check if the content of each chapter is outdated is a hassle a user shouldn't have to deal with.

results.content:
Very well structured course, with a perfect balance between lesson and exercise. Explanation is lively and well articulated.
Unfortunately, some of the features of Angular2 have changed quite a bit between the recording and the final (?) Angular release, and (being totally new to web development) I had a tough time figuring out the new ways, because a lot of what you find on web q&a also mixes up the various versions. This course has excellent appendices explaining how to evolve, but I only noticed those at the end. If you start off new, you'll want to install the final release, and I think you will be frustrated stumbling into stuff shown in the videos that no longer exists.

results.content:
Another great course from Mosh. So the bad bits first which are nothing to do with Mosh and his course. The angular version is dated which means that some of the NPM (especially typings on underscore) do not work. Having said that, the content that is covered is excellent. If you have this course + one on the database and API side you can write exceptionally slick enterprise sites. 

There is a lot to get through, it can easily several weeks to complete but when finished you have built a slick looking site in Angular. 

In all of Mosh's courses (I have a taken a few now!) he always build something which at the end of it you have learnt the technology and are amazed by it also. 

Hats off to Mosh again. Another great course. During this course I received the crash course free update to take from beta to the latest version which is incremental add on to this excellent course.

results.content:
Mosh is a very well spoken instructor, that very clearly explains his reasoning behind things, and makes a habit of telling you the ins and outs of why you are writing the code you are writing, instead of just telling you the what. Overall a pretty good course.

That said, the last 10% or so of the course is a little out-dated, but you can still get it working by some basic googling. Also, if you follow along with the coding, it's likely going to take you more than 10 hours to complete due to the speed at which the instructor writes code.

results.content:
for beginners with no java experience, this course does not explain the basics well enough..the examples are fine, but the "why" questions are not answered very well. It is also at time difficult to understand what Mosh is saying as his accent at time inhibits what he is saying when he speaks too fast....no offence.
There seems to be too much code which is thought that the student already knows, already has had experience with, and when the tests are done, this code just magically appears with a slight giggle as if someone was saying " haha, bet you didnt know this"..quite annoying. 
I understand it is a very difficult language but I still believe it is not so much for beginners/medium exposed individuals but more for those who have programmed in javascript or angular to more of a degree than I have. I shall trudge forward because ANY information gained is always educational

Mosh you have done a great job! Thank you!!!

results.content:
I like the practical approach, but it requires an update in the following subjects:
-Bootstrap icons are no longer available, and now they need to be replaced with something else, like font-awesome
-Http module isn't working anymore as documented. Nowadays it's used HttpClient module instead, which is completely different.
-RxJs also is a quite outdated and many of the examples require a significant time spent to overcome the incompatibilities.

It doesn't require that much to update this course, just a couple of short videos explaining how to create the equivalent code with the new Angular and Bootstrap versions

results.content:
I decided to save this review until I finished the course completely.  For those that do not know the back-story,
Mosh created this Angular 2 course while it was still in Beta.  He got an early jump being one of the first on Udemy 
to have an Angular 2 course and he did an excellent job.  Unfortunately, from the Beta versions to RC versions to the Final release, Google introduced a lot of 'breaking changes'.  

From there, Mosh created a some PDFs talking about the changes each time they occurred.  Then, he created a video talking about the changes.  Then, he started introducing more videos/pdfs that talked about even more 'breaking changes'.  At some point people were confused about all the changes and asked Mosh to update the videos.

Having to re-records all the videos would be a HUGE undertaking.  Mosh's opinion (and some fellow viewers) was, "If you want to be a developer, you should be able to figure out & fix this on your own b/c these things happen in the real world".   I do not agree with this argument, but for what I paid for the course, I can't complain.  This course is easily worth 10X as much, even with it being outdated.

Since I did not want to spend several hours troubleshooting and upgrading the tutorial projects to Angular 2 Final, I 
took the course as it was recorded with Angular 2 Beta and all my code was based on the Beta version.  For the most part everything went smoothly.  There were a few times where things did not work and Google had removed the Beta documentation.  Also, there were a few times where the notes/examples were done in Angular 2 Final, but my project was still a Beta project. 


Final Thoughts 

Since I have finished the course and WOULD NOT retake it even if he did re-record it with the changes, I will give my 
opinion for the sake of Mosh and future viewers.  I think Mosh must re-record or re-create the videos.  This is supposed to be a course on "Angular 2", not "Angular 2 Beta with update notes on the Final version".  There are other authors coming out with Angular 2 courses which are great courses and are completely built with Angular 2 Final. 

Anyone with a choice between a new, up-to-date course on Angular 2 course OR THIS course with outdated material would choose the newer course.  You can call the changes minor and only syntactical, but the material is still outdated.  One or two syntax changes is fine, but when you have 10 different breaking changes, and add that on top of trying to learn Angular and Typescript, it can be a pain when you working through the videos.  Is the project breaking b/c I did something wrong or is it a different syntax/module?  Also note, Mosh is not one to answer questions in the class forum.  

Rating 

The rating of this course is something I struggled with.  On one hand Mosh did a great job of putting together the course and hands on projects.  On the other hand, because of the back and forth changes, it was hard to follow at times and is an outdated course (even though its only a few months old).  I also have to compare Mosh with some other instructors who DO answer questions on their forum.  Mosh might call this hand-holding, but the whole point of taking this course is to speed up the learning process.  He should here to expedite my journey, not tell me RTFM if you want to be a real developer.

I decided to save this review until I finished the course completely. For those that do not know the back-story,
Mosh created this Angular 2 course while it was still in Beta. He got an early jump being one of the first on Udemy
to have an Angular 2 course and he did an excellent job. Unfortunately, from the Beta versions to RC versions to the Final release, Google introduced a lot of 'breaking changes'.

From there, Mosh created a some PDFs talking about the changes each time they occurred. Then, he created a video talking about the changes. Then, he started introducing more videos/pdfs that talked about even more 'breaking changes'. At some point people were confused about all the changes and asked Mosh to update the videos.

Having to re-records all the videos would be a HUGE undertaking. Mosh's opinion (and some fellow viewers) was, "If you want to be a developer, you should be able to figure out & fix this on your own b/c these things happen in the real world". I do not agree with this argument, but for what I paid for the course, I can't complain. This course is easily worth 10X as much, even with it being outdated.

Since I did not want to spend several hours troubleshooting and upgrading the tutorial projects to Angular 2 Final, I
took the course as it was recorded with Angular 2 Beta and all my code was based on the Beta version. For the most part everything went smoothly. There were a few times where things did not work and Google had removed the Beta documentation. Also, there were a few times where the notes/examples were done in Angular 2 Final, but my project was still a Beta project.

Final Thoughts

Since I have finished the course and WOULD NOT retake it even if he did re-record it with the changes, I will give my
opinion for the sake of Mosh and future viewers. I think Mosh must re-record or re-create the videos. This is supposed to be a course on "Angular 2", not "Angular 2 Beta with update notes on the Final version". There are other authors coming out with Angular 2 courses which are great courses and are completely built with Angular 2 Final.

Anyone with a choice between a new, up-to-date course on Angular 2 course OR THIS course with outdated material would choose the newer course. You can call the changes minor and only syntactical, but the material is still outdated. One or two syntax changes is fine, but when you have 10 different breaking changes, and add that on top of trying to learn Angular and Typescript, it can be a pain when you working through the videos. Is the project breaking b/c I did something wrong or is it a different syntax/module? Also note, Mosh is not one to answer questions in the class forum.

Rating

The rating of this course is something I struggled with. On one hand Mosh did a great job of putting together the course and hands on projects. On the other hand, because of the back and forth changes, it was hard to follow at times and is an outdated course (even though its only a few months old). I also have to compare Mosh with some other instructors who DO answer questions on their forum. Mosh might call this hand-holding, but the whole point of taking this course is to speed up the learning process. He should here to expedite my journey, not tell me RTFM if you want to be a real developer.

results.content: Mosh is a great lecturer but unfortunately he is very stubborn to inject his "user preferences" to students which are very subjective.. For instance as a windows user I hate using command line to create a simple folder.. I am thinking was it mkdir or mk - dir, or dir-mk... come on I should not even think about it here.. Just go create a new folder in windows explorer or MacOS.. super simple for WHOEVER uses computer.. Not only for the folks who used to use terminal too look more "hackerish" unless it is a MUST ...  I have found my self getting distracted during the course just because of trying to following him.. Like opening a file through command line in VS Code. I was getting an error. Spend half an hour then I realized "what... what am I doing.. just go ahead and click the file then click open and select file in VS Code... Thats it.. What I am trying to point here is, for the folks who are not familiar with terminal (which I believe expecially the new grads nowadays not familiar with terminal commands), they may just think that "oh this is the way to open the file to start coding in angular 4..." To me it is showing your right ear with your left hand... But again this is subjective, someone else can say the vice versa.. That is why I would mention that "oh there is another way to open this through this etc... but I prefer to open like that".. So people dont focus that part and waste their time to make it work. But anyways, this is just my feedback. Especially for the new students, it just makes it more complicated my opinion. Rather than the topic itself, people spending more time  with configuration or terminal commands.. I had the similar experience with his previous courses with Re-Sharper.. Yes I use resharper which is probably the best tool I ever used on VS but again.. the class should not be on some user specific preferences.. people who are paying is paying to learn the fundamentals not the tools to get better at it... Last but not least, he is a great lecturer, but for this course I found my self that spending more time on the other stuff and getting distracted during the course so much.. This rating is specific for this course which does not change that he is a very good lecturer. Cheers.

results.content:
Every course Mosh does it fantastic.  Just fantastic.  I've learned so much from his courses.

A note to potential students.  Right now (Dec 2016) this course is based on Angular 2 *beta*, not Angular 2 final release.  There are significant changes between beta and final.  Mosh does his best to illustrate the changes as you go along, but as you are watching him code, you'll see him doing things differently than you will do them in Angular 2...  I'd love a course update to Angular 2 Final, but I understand it's a huge process.
results.content_html:

results.content:
This course is great for many reasons. The intro is great and the course structure is well organized. Everything is introduced in a nice and friendly way. The author takes his time to show code advantages of Angular 2 compared with vanilla javascript. This is a big deal when you want to understand the layers of the framework. The missing half star is because of a few suggestions for the autor.
When coding from the start there is some deprecated code (this will eventually go away as you code along, but can be disturbing as a new coder). Beauty of structure is always in the eyes of the beholder, but perhaps a bit of folder structure from the beginning would be good. Throughout most of the beginning the entirety of the app resides in the app-folder and this could be broken into subfolders for easy maintainability of larger projects. It would also be nice to have the finished app code for all the lectures, perhaps even as a git-exercise? You could create branches we could checkout if we wanted to check with your code, which is much easier than stopping the lecture and rewinding to check why something isn't working.
All in all a great course!
results.content_html:
This course is great for many reasons. The intro is great and the course structure is well organized. Everything is introduced in a nice and friendly way. The author takes his time to show code advantages of Angular 2 compared with vanilla javascript. This is a big deal when you want to understand the layers of the framework. The missing half star is because of a few suggestions for the autor.
When coding from the start there is some deprecated code (this will eventually go away as you code along, but can be disturbing as a new coder). Beauty of structure is always in the eyes of the beholder, but perhaps a bit of folder structure from the beginning would be good. Throughout most of the beginning the entirety of the app resides in the app-folder and this could be broken into subfolders for easy maintainability of larger projects. It would also be nice to have the finished app code for all the lectures, perhaps even as a git-exercise? You could create branches we could checkout if we wanted to check with your code, which is much easier than stopping the lecture and rewinding to check why something isn't working.
All in all a great course!

results.content:
I am a relative new comer to Angular 2 and Ionic 2.

I've been programming 20+ years mostly in .NET.

Recently I took a new lead dev role at a new small software company rolling out a big mobile product in Ionic 2.

The current devs are fluent in Angular 2 and Ionic 2. I am not. My new boss wants me to prototype advanced components with native functionality at light speed. Up to now the learning curve felt lonely and steep.

This weekend I needed to master Ionic 2 forms. Within 5 minutes of watching Mosh's section on forms I felt my shoulders relax. I knew Mosh had my back.

Owning this series is like having Mosh as your "go-to guru".

I've taken Mosh's ASP.NET MVC and Entity Framework courses as well as his full stack dev in .NET course. I know of no faster more enjoyable way to absorb entire learning curves than having Mosh demystify the topic and use real coding tasks to illuminate application.

Good teachers are almost impossible to find. Mosh is a great teacher.

results.content:
Interesting and detailed course about Angular 2. The overall pace of the course is not too fast, allowing you to easily follow the content.

The  course covers a lot of topics, including the basics of Angular 2, the basics of ReactiveX and the basics of TypeScript and even some useful shortcuts for VS Code.

The main reason I'm not giving 5/5 is because I would love to hear some more about unit testing as well. Though, since Angular 2 is mainly vanilla TypeScript with some annotations, I suppose it's a lot easier to test than AngularJS (1).

I did find out about some cool tools like SystemJS which I had not heard about before, but overall, I would suggest skipping this course.

results.content: The explanations are good. The instructor is an active speaker which makes it more interesting to watch. I have had some issues with the setup. New versions of npm are out already as are new versions of angular and easier ways to install them. I had very little understanding of nodejs and npm and after some research ended up using nvm with a different startup project. A simple explanation of how the systems work would make troubleshooting and further research easier. This is not a big flaw though and it is still a very good course so far I'm very happy with it. I do recommend also mentioning powershell as an alternative to the command prompt and it's also worth noting that in some cases you'll need to run powershell as administrator.

results.content: Mosh is a truly amazing instructor - engaging and knowledgeable, charismatic and systematic. I'm 35% into the course, and while I cannot guarantee about the rest of the course, I don't see any reason to believe it will get downhill from this point. There seems to be some controversy about the course not being up-to-date in light of the breaking changes which occur at this stage in Angular 2 itself. While I have experienced this myself on one occasion, I find it a minor issue (which Mosh addresses by adding notes in the final section). By searching the usual online channels for more up-to-date information to the issue I had, I realized that pretty much the entire Internet is currently not up-to-date on Angular 2, and this will be an ongoing issue for a while. I don't think these concerns about the course can outweigh the value of having such an excellent instructor.

results.content:
Excellent course to get my feet wet in Angular. Mosh is easy to understand and a pleasant lecturer. He takes time to explain core principles of coding along with the Angular training. 

When I took the course there is still a couple hold-outs from Angular 5 left in the course. I was working from an Angular 6 installation. The import format for rxjs changed between Angular 5 and 6, I had t install the rxjs-compat npm package to follow along. Also the default npm installation of bootstrap is now v4. It doesn't include the glyph icons used in some lectures. I needed to uninstall v4 and specify v3 when installing the bootstrap npm (google it). Just a couple/few snags in version advancement, but other than that, great course.
results.content_html:

results.content:
After reading every book I could get I was not able to start a project. But this course makes me start working. Mosh does a great job! 

I also like the web-class-approach to get teached whenever *I* am ready. I repeat parts of the class to get the tasks on the end of the lections done, so I can focus on things I missed the first time watching it.

I also like to watch or repeat parts on my iphone. I can read the code shown also on this little device easily.

Mosh was doing a really good job. The excercises after some lessons are _very_ motivating and I could programm little useful well known components. The lessons are great to program along with the teacher. 

But there is a frustrating gap between beta and final version of Angular 2. Everything starts well with a downloadable seedprojekt made in Angular2/beta. In the middle of the complete course there are lections with observables, everything broke down when trying to program along because jquery($-variable) was biting proteractor($-variable). I could not deal with it and restarted the course with angular-final and angular-cli. But also with the "latest changes" I could not make the gap from beta to final of Angular2. At this point I was working for 10 days to make the course run again with Angular2/final. In the end I gave up. The Questions and Answers from udemy are a great idea, but did not help enough. 

What I think: Mosh is really a GREAT teacher. But with sooo many students the course should be made fresh with the final version of Angular2.
results.content_html:
After reading every book I could get I was not able to start a project. But this course makes me start working. Mosh does a great job!

I also like the web-class-approach to get teached whenever *I* am ready. I repeat parts of the class to get the tasks on the end of the lections done, so I can focus on things I missed the first time watching it.

I also like to watch or repeat parts on my iphone. I can read the code shown also on this little device easily.

Mosh was doing a really good job. The excercises after some lessons are _very_ motivating and I could programm little useful well known components. The lessons are great to program along with the teacher.

But there is a frustrating gap between beta and final version of Angular 2. Everything starts well with a downloadable seedprojekt made in Angular2/beta. In the middle of the complete course there are lections with observables, everything broke down when trying to program along because jquery($-variable) was biting proteractor($-variable). I could not deal with it and restarted the course with angular-final and angular-cli. But also with the "latest changes" I could not make the gap from beta to final of Angular2. At this point I was working for 10 days to make the course run again with Angular2/final. In the end I gave up. The Questions and Answers from udemy are a great idea, but did not help enough.

What I think: Mosh is really a GREAT teacher. But with sooo many students the course should be made fresh with the final version of Angular2.

results.content:
This is how all courses should be, and I truly hope that others will watch this, and learn how to build one. 
I've taking lots of classes and training, both in academic and job related.
After going through most of this course, I found Mosh as a trainer from birth, and truly enjoy taking the class.
If knowledge is the reason you consider taking this course, knowledge is what you will get, and in the best, and fun way. 
The course is build on projects/tasks to follow, and with Mosh guidance, I found it challenging but still possible to complete, and the end results, it is curved into your brain.
So, it not yet another course that just "dump" the information with example, but Mosh takes the time and explain who and why it works.

Can't wait to start with Mosh advance class.

results.content:
Mosh is an outstanding instructor!  After taking my first course from him (ASP.NET MVC 5), I immediately bought all of his other courses and I'm working my way through them.  This course, like the others are VERY thorough and provide great exercises that are challenging and reinforce learning.

Angular is a difficult and complex subject.  I'm new to Angular and to be honest, I'm having a tough time wrapping my head around it.  But Mosh breaks it down in a way that makes it easy to digest.  He walks you through tasks in baby steps and is careful to point out and demonstrate potential pitfalls.

It will be some time before I'm comfortable writing Angular apps.  But I guarantee that I will continue to come back to this course and use it as an instructional reference.

By far the best Angular 2 course that you can find on the internet. I am now confident that I have solid understanding of the basics of Angular 2, thanks to the wonderful tutoring by Mosh. I have even enrolled for the Angular advanced course by Mosh which I am planning to complete in the next week or so. 

I do have a suggestion. What is really missing in this course is the basics of Angular 2 testing. It need not be exhaustive but a basic walkthrough could've made it complete. But this shortcoming does not keep me from rating it 5 stars. If it had the Testing module also, I would've rated it 6!!!

results.content:
The course was easy to understand and well explained. Through the course he introduced various tools like VS code, Emmet plugin, Underscore.js which were all new to me. 

I was bit worried when I started learning this as the lessons were based on a older version of angular. But at the end instructor explained whats new in the final release and how to use them.

The final project was also very well made. I was surprised to see each step of the project so meticulously added to the github as separate commits and we could see what changes need to be made at each step. And the final project covered everything we learned in this course.

Great job.

#Update
-----------
Instructor now added fresh videos with Angular 4! Awesome, thanks a lot!

results.content:
The course was simply amazing. Mosh is simply great at teaching whatever he picks to teach. I have taken other courses of his as well and have found each one of them amazing.

My only complaint with this course is that it lacks 1 video where the student should be taught how to create a new Angular project with a specific Angular/cli version. As when creating a new project, by default the version is set to the current version (i.e. 7.0 at present) while the course teaches version 4.0.

Now some of the stuff that was a part of Angular 4, has been deprecated now (like HTTP). But a student working with a new project with Angular version set to 7 (which he may not be aware of) will face many issues while following the HTTP section of this course.

So please add a video teaching to create a new Angular project with a specific version and then this course will deserve nothing less than a 5-star.

results.content:
Mosh is a great instructor, he is very clear and concise and breaks down his examples into small "components" (drum roll please) that make it easy for the listener to understand what is going on and learn at a relaxed pace.

He also goes over the variations of how to implement various aspects of Angular to give you an understanding of how Angular implements shorthands or how other developers might code differently to his preferences and even leaves code out at times to show you what might go wrong and what to look for when debugging.

Having never used Angular before, I'm really impressed at how easy it was to understand the concepts and even managed most of the examples without having to refer back to the lectures and that is in no small part due to Mosh's understanding of Angular and how well he explains everything.

If you can't already tell, I'm really impressed Mosh - keep up the good work!

SO far so good, but I wish he would explain WHY we're doing certain things.  Adding code out of thin air can be a bit much.

Why not just build a real world application from start to finish.  Explain the who, what, when, where, why, how of all aspects of the development cycle then have the exercises do what we just learned.  Then move on to the next.  Different components need to be learned in order so that the delivery is continuous.
By the time the course if finished the developer will know how to build an app to use in the real world.

results.content:
Generally the course was good. And I really liked how sincerely Mosh came across: As an instructor who really wanted to help you learn Angular 2. Where I felt the course fell apart, however, was that, I thought it tried to take on too much, and in the process, some areas of Angular 2 did not get enough attention. It's a very large task to get one's head around Angular 2. There's a great deal of foreign territory that you'll be exploring in your leaning process, many concepts that will feel vague and their purpose unclear and the way they are tied to the rest of the framework somewhat nebulous. I can see that this subject would not be easy to teach.

As an example of something that confused me after I was left to my own devices was the subject of @input metadata tag; when does one use this as opposed to just taking a component property and assigning it to a Dom property. It wasn't until I went to the Angular 2 documentation that I understood that one usage was intended as the target of the element attribute (@input) and the property assignment for the source of the assignment (right side of equal sign) to the attribute . This is something that Mosh could have done a more thorough job of explaining. Sometimes it is necessary, especially with a subject as complex as Angular 2, to state and restate various concepts in as many ways that you can think of in order to help your students make the necessary connections. I actually went back and listened to part of the lecture on @input and felt that Mosh could have done a better job of connecting the concepts.

I don't wish to sound overly critical of this course. I learned a tremendous amount from it and the material I'm sure is extremely challenging to teach. There are so many new concepts and so much idiosyncratic syntax that one can be left thoroughly perplexed at times. This was an excellent first pass at attempting to teach this challenging material. I believe that Mosh will only make it better. I would start by limiting the scope of the material to some extent. And lessons could also be learned from the Angular 2 documentation; as I was reading the documentation, I was pleasantly surprised that it frequently second-guessed the questions that were floating through my mind. I think this course would be even better than it is if Mosh slowed down some and did some more second-guessing as to what might be perplexing his students. 

As a brief background of where I'm coming from: I've been a senior software developer for over 20 years and have always worked with Microsoft technologies, including SQL Server, C#, Asp.Net, MVC, Web Api and their related tools and technologies.

results.content:
I have downgraded the rating to 1 star due to fact that despite requests from several students the instructor has not updated the course and neither responds to requests on Discussion Forums.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The instructor has a good presentation style and teaches the content well. This was a good course when I bought it but I am giving it 2 stars for a couple of reasons.

1. The course is not updated to the final version of Angular 2, though the final version has been out for a while now.

2. Instead of re-working the videos to update the content and code examples, he has added sections at the end that lists the changes. This creates a difficult learning experience for a beginner as code they learn in the first few videos does not work correctly and they have to scroll all the way to the end to get the latest changes. This is not an optimum learning experience for a beginner.

3. The instructor is unresponsive on the Discussion Forums. As a beginner, you will have questions and not having those questions answered leads to a subpar learning experience. There are questions in the forum that have been unanswered for the past 25 days!!

IMHO, this was a good course when it started, but the lack of updates and a lack of response from the instructor have really brought this down. I had to buy another Angular 2 course that was updated to get a better learning experience.

results.content:
NOT FOR BEGINNERS. While the instructor is great, and I can see this course being extremely useful at a higher level, it is absolutely not for beginners. 

Compared to: The Complete Guide to Angular 2, this course breezes through core concepts. In one section with have literally went through Components, Services, and Injections. 

In the complete guide course, these topics have their own dedicated sections.

If you are a true beginner I would recommend The Complete Guide to Angular 2, as it explains main Angular 2 concepts much more clearly, and come back to this after you have finished that course. 

Disclaimer: I voted this as 1/2 star, to get the rating total down, not due to it's course content which is very good, but due to the fact that it's very beginner friendly. 

The real rating if you are excluding the beginner facet is probably a solid 3-4.

If you are a true beginner I would recommend The Complete Guide to Angular 2, as it explains main Angular 2 concepts much more clearly, and come back to this after you have finished that course.

Disclaimer: I voted this as 1/2 star, to get the rating total down, not due to it's course content which is very good, but due to the fact that it's very beginner friendly.

The real rating if you are excluding the beginner facet is probably a solid 3-4.

results.content:
Mosh never lets me down. I'm so glad he jumped on Angular 2 as I was dying for a solid introduction to the framework ASAP and he sure provides! Just cross your fingers that he does a complete course update upon final release. We're now at RC4.

This course has been illuminating on several unexpected levels. I came into it with zero exposure to TypeScript or Node.JS and I'm getting comfortable with TypeScript and mildly acquainted with Node as a side benefit! If you don't know these technologies, don't worry. As long as you're comfortable coding and understand OOP and class structures, it will come together.

I gotta commend his exercises in particular. They're of just the right level of complexity and he gives just the right amount of guidance before you start to let you feel confident digging in and trying until you get it. Of course, even if you do you'll probably get a nice "Aha!" moment when he shows you a better way.

The course is right to the point with simple explanations, examples, and exercises yet deep exposure to the  framework's inner workings.

Thanks again Mosh. Keep it up!

results.content:
Before explaining my rating of this course, I would like to say the follow:

I respect Mosh Hamadani in every aspect.  I consider him my mentor.  

The Angular 2 course is extremely well thought out and delivered by Mosh.

Having said this, however, the course should have been redone at any cost to the "Final" version of Angular.  Although Mosh stated that the changes from the Beta version to the Final version should be easy to follow, I really found trying to understand Mosh's code, which uses the Beta version, and my implementing this same code in the Final version of Angular to be super tough, confusing, and very time consuming on this end.

My conclusion then is the following:  this is really a 5 star course, and Mosh Hamadani is a 6 star instructor, but the fact that the course uses the Beta version of Angular instead of the Final version of Angular makes me rate it as a 3, not a 5.  My apologies to Mosh in advance, because he has in fact done me a great service by creating this course, but I do feel I need to tell others my experience.

results.content: I think Mosh's teaching style is excellent but there are many technical and consistency problems with the course.  Often "surprise" code changes will appear out of nowhere so following along is often impossible.  I've spent hours trying to make the programs work and often have to give up. The downloadable code is frequently incomplete or has usually not worked.  Worse, as this course is a mixture of beta and final Angular2, Mosh has left it to the student to figure out how to fix the bugs.  For a very experience developer, it may be possible to follow along with this confusion but as a newer developers, I find the course extremely frustrating and almost a waste of time.  I would like to see Mosh rewrite the course properly as I think he's a good instructor.
results.content_html: I think Mosh's teaching style is excellent but there are many technical and consistency problems with the course. Often "surprise" code changes will appear out of nowhere so following along is often impossible. I've spent hours trying to make the programs work and often have to give up. The downloadable code is frequently incomplete or has usually not worked. Worse, as this course is a mixture of beta and final Angular2, Mosh has left it to the student to figure out how to fix the bugs. For a very experience developer, it may be possible to follow along with this confusion but as a newer developers, I find the course extremely frustrating and almost a waste of time. I would like to see Mosh rewrite the course properly as I think he's a good instructor.

results.content:
First off, thank you Mosh for teaching us Angular2 and providing the necessary resources for us to build our own applications. His lectures are somewhat easy to follow (but that is because I am very experienced with Angular1) and his tone in teaching is very friendly and approachable. 

I understand that Angular2, in the past year, has undergone a lot of syntactical changes (amongst other things) so the content is not always up to date. I will be honest and say I spent a lot of time figuring out how newest Angular2 concepts worked because some of the videos were outdated. I also spent a lot of time looking for resources that Mosh said was attached the certain lectures.

All in all, this was a great course and I learned a lot. Mosh also forced me to code many things for my own (rather than just giving us the answers, albeit, solutions are available). This gave me the opportunity to be more fluent in Angular2.

I signed up for your advanced topics course for Angular2 as well. Looking forward to it and hope it uses the newest version of Angular2 for your videos.
